name: 1,3-diethyl-5-methylbenzene
Reason: 1,3-diethyl-5-methylbenzene has a melting point that can be predicted by considering its structural components. The basic unit for comparison is ethylbenzene, which has a melting point of -169.2°C. The introduction of two additional phenyl groups linked in a linear fashion raises the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions and molecular weight. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions and molecular weight. Additionally, the methyl group introduces a bulky side chain, which can contribute approximately +10°C due to steric hindrance and increasing the molecular volume. The ethyl group also introduces a bulky side chain, which can contribute approximately +10°C due to steric hindrance and increasing the molecular volume.
